That's a great idea! Getting a mechanic's inspection or appraisal can provide an independent assessment of the bike's condition, which can help build trust with potential buyers and give them more confidence in the purchase. It can also give you a better understanding of the bike's condition and help you price it more accurately.

A mechanic's inspection can cover various aspects of the bike, including:

* Engine performance and condition
* Transmission and drivetrain condition
* Brake system condition
* Suspension and steering condition
* Electrical system condition
* Cosmetic condition, including any damage or wear

The inspection report can provide a detailed assessment of the bike's condition, highlighting any issues or areas that need attention. This can be especially helpful if you're not familiar with the bike's mechanical condition or if you're selling it to a buyer who wants a thorough inspection.

An appraisal, on the other hand, can provide a written estimate of the bike's value based on its condition, mileage, and market demand. This can help you determine a fair and competitive price for the bike.

Keep in mind that a mechanic's inspection or appraisal may cost you some money, but it can be a worthwhile investment if it helps you sell the bike more quickly and for a better price.

Here's an example of how you could mention the inspection or appraisal in your listing:

"2007 Kawasaki Ninja 650 for sale! This bike has been garage-kept for over a year and has not been ridden in that time. As a result, it's been well-maintained and has been protected from the elements. I've recently had a mechanic's inspection performed, which revealed [insert any issues or areas that need attention]. The inspection report is available upon request. The bike has [insert mileage] miles and has been regularly serviced. It features [insert features, such as ABS brakes, etc.]. I'm looking for a serious buyer who will give this bike the attention it deserves. Please contact me with any questions or to schedule a test ride."

Remember to be transparent and honest in your listing, and make sure to provide any supporting documentation, such as the inspection report or appraisal, to potential buyers. Good luck with the sale!
